title: MEPs reject Romanian and Hungarian nominees for European Commission
text:
Rovama Plumb and László Trócsányi | Source images by EPA MEPs reject Romanian and Hungarian nominees for European Commission Blow to von der Leyen as Parliament panel cites concerns over conflicts of interest.

Members of the European Parliament on Thursday rejected the Romanian and Hungarian nominees for the next European Commission over concerns about potential conflicts of interest.

The decisions by the Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee represented a first major setback for Ursula von der Leyen since she was elected to lead the next Commission, which is due to take office on November 1.

The committee voted to block Rovana Plumb, the nominee to be transport commissioner, from going forward to a confirmation hearing, following a closed-door session during which they questioned the Romanian over financial concerns.

They also blocked the nomination of Hungary's László Trócsányi for the post of European commissioner for neighborhood and enlargement after a similar session.

Speaking as news of the rejections emerged, Commission spokeswoman Mina Andreeva said: "What this means for now is that the procedure is suspended."

Both Plumb and Trócsányi had been due to face confirmation hearings from specialist committees next week.

Andreeva said the Legal Affairs Committee's decisions does "not necessarily mean that now a new candidate automatically has to be proposed."

She said the next steps would depend on how the Parliament chose to proceed, in coordination with von der Leyen. But a Parliament official said the legislature would soon make clear in writing that the two nominees are not acceptable.

Fifteen committee members voted to reject Plumb’s candidacy while six voted in her favor. There were two abstentions. Plumb, a member of the Socialists and Democrats group, was called before the committee to account for two loans worth nearly €1 million that she did not declare in her original financial declaration scrutinized by MEPs.

The committee voted against Trócsányi by a margin of 11 against and nine in favor. Two MEPs abstained.

Sergey Lagodinsky, the vice president of the committee, told POLITICO: "The two [nominees] have been rejected while 24 were cleared."

Lagodinsky said the next step will be to send a letter to von der Leyen, "underlining our position and deciding what further is going to happen.

"The process is for now suspended until the Commission president reacts," he added.

The approval of the Legal Affairs Committee is an essential precondition for parliamentary hearings to take place. Without its green light, EU rules state that the confirmation procedure for the commissioner-designate is suspended. The next step is for the Parliament's president to ask von der Leyen how she wishes to proceed.

A Parliament spokesperson said a rejection of a candidate in the Legal Affairs Committee is unprecedented and "we have to see what will happen.”

"It’s clear that the hearing can not take place," the spokesperson added.

Hans von der Burchard contributed reporting.
description: Blow to von der Leyen as Parliament panel cites concerns over conflicts of interest.
